messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 61 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: On the Pauli Spectrum of 𝖰𝖠𝖢⁰

Paper Abstract: Abstract The circuit class 𝖰𝖠𝖢0superscript𝖰𝖠𝖢0\mathsf{QAC}^{0} was introduced by Moore (1999) as a model for constant depth quantum circuits where the gate set includes many-qubit Toffoli gates. Proving lower bounds against such circuits is a longstanding challenge in quantum circuit complexity; in particular, showing that polynomial-size 𝖰𝖠𝖢0superscript𝖰𝖠𝖢0\mathsf{QAC}^{0} cannot compute the parity function has remained an open question for over 20 years. In this work, we identify a notion of the Pauli spectrum of 𝖰𝖠𝖢0superscript𝖰𝖠𝖢0\mathsf{QAC}^{0} circuits, which can be viewed as the quantum analogue of the Fourier spectrum of classical 𝖠𝖢0superscript𝖠𝖢0\mathsf{AC}^{0} circuits. We conjecture that the Pauli spectrum of 𝖰𝖠𝖢0superscript𝖰𝖠𝖢0\mathsf{QAC}^{0} circuits satisfies low-degree concentration, in analogy to the famous Linial, Nisan, Mansour theorem on the low-degree Fourier concentration of 𝖠𝖢0superscript𝖠𝖢0\mathsf{AC}^{0} circuits. If true, this conjecture immediately implies that polynomial-size 𝖰𝖠𝖢0superscript𝖰𝖠𝖢0\mathsf{QAC}^{0} circuits cannot compute parity. We prove this conjecture for the class of depth-d𝑑d, polynomial-size 𝖰𝖠𝖢0superscript𝖰𝖠𝖢0\mathsf{QAC}^{0} circuits with at most nO​(1/d)superscript𝑛𝑂1𝑑n^{O(1/d)} auxiliary qubits. We obtain new circuit lower bounds and learning results as applications: this class of circuits cannot correctly compute • the n𝑛n-bit parity function on more than (12+2−Ω​(n1/d))12superscript2Ωsuperscript𝑛1𝑑(\frac{1}{2}+2^{-\Omega(n^{1/d})})-fraction of inputs, and • the n𝑛n-bit majority function on more than (12+O​(n−1/4))12𝑂superscript𝑛14(\frac{1}{2}+O(n^{-1/4}))-fraction of inputs. Additionally we show that this class of 𝖰𝖠𝖢0superscript𝖰𝖠𝖢0\mathsf{QAC}^{0} circuits with limited auxiliary qubits can be learned with quasipolynomial sample complexity, giving the first learning result for 𝖰𝖠𝖢0superscript𝖰𝖠𝖢0\mathsf{QAC}^{0} circuits. More broadly, our results add evidence that “Pauli-analytic” techniques can be a powerful tool in studying quantum circuits.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 61 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 61"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "NLTS Hamiltonians from good quantum codes",
        "A polynomial-time classical algorithm for noisy random circuit sampling",
        "Hand-waving and interpretive dance: an introductory course on tensor networks",
        "Computing with a full memory: Catalytic space",
        "Small depth quantum circuits",
        "Testing juntas nearly optimally",
        "A quantum processor based on coherent transport of entangled atom arrays",
        "The average sensitivity of bounded-depth circuits",
        "Poly-logarithmic independence fools A​C0𝐴superscript𝐶0AC^{0} circuits",
        "Nearly optimal algorithms for testing and learning quantum junta channels",
        "Learning quantum processes and hamiltonians via the pauli transfer matrix",
        "Exponential separations between learning with and without quantum memory",
        "Pseudorandom generators from polarizing random walks",
        "Pseudorandom generators from the second Fourier level and applications to AC0 with parity gates",
        "Testing and learning quantum juntas nearly optimally",
        "Local Hamiltonians whose ground states are hard to approximate",
        "Low-degree learning and the metric entropy of polynomials",
        "Quantum lower bounds for fanout",
        "Monotonicity testing over general poset domains",
        "Parity, circuits, and the polynomial-time hierarchy",
        "Implementing a fast unbounded quantum fanout gate using power-law interactions",
        "Quantum fan-out: Circuit optimizations and technology modeling",
        "Noise sensitivity of Boolean functions and percolation, volume 5",
        "Computational Limitations for Small Depth Circuits",
        "A slight sharpening of LMN",
        "On the correlation of parity and small-depth circuits",
        "Learning to predict arbitrary quantum processes",
        "Predicting many properties of a quantum system from very few measurements",
        "Quantum fan-out is powerful",
        "A satisfiability algorithm for A​C​0𝐴𝐶0AC0",
        "Cryptographic hardness of distribution-specific learning",
        "Agnostically learning halfspaces",
        "Learning decision trees using the Fourier spectrum",
        "On monotonicity testing and boolean isoperimetric-type theorems",
        "Tensor networks and quantum algorithms",
        "Towards robust quantum computation",
        "Constant depth circuits, Fourier transform and learnability",
        "Hardness of classically simulating the one-clean-qubit model",
        "Quantum boolean functions",
        "Quantum circuits: Fanout, parity, and counting",
        "Quantum-process tomography: Resource analysis of different strategies",
        "Quantum Computation and Quantum Information: 10th Anniversary Edition",
        "Hardness vs randomness",
        "Analysis of Boolean Functions",
        "Depth-2 QAC circuits cannot simulate quantum parity",
        "Lower bounds on the size of bounded depth circuits over a complete basis with logical addition",
        "Bounds on the Q​A​C​0𝑄𝐴𝐶0QAC0 Complexity of Approximating Parity",
        "Characterizing midcircuit measurements on a superconducting qubit using gate set tomography",
        "Oracle separation of BQP and PH",
        "Quantum Talagrand, KKL and Friedgut’s theorems and the learnability of quantum Boolean functions",
        "Parity vs. ac0 with simple quantum preprocessing",
        "Information processing in dynamical systems: Foundations of harmony theory",
        "Noncommutative Bohnenblust-Hille inequality in the Heisenberg-Weyl and Gell-Mann bases with applications to fast learning",
        "Tight bounds on the Fourier spectrum of A​C​0𝐴𝐶0AC0",
        "Renyi-entropic bounds on quantum communication",
        "Efficiently preparing Schrödinger’s cat, fractons and non-Abelian topological order in quantum devices",
        "Noncommutative Bohnenblust–Hille inequalities",
        "Property testing of unitary operators",
        "The theory of quantum information",
        "Quantum Information Theory",
        "Separating the polynomial time hierarchy by oracles"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 61 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in On the Pauli Spectrum of 𝖰𝖠𝖢⁰, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
